works_covered: The Interpretation of Dreams (continuation and major sections)

positions.position: Verbal malformations in dreams resemble those in paranoia, hysteria, and obsessions, sharing a common source with linguistic tricks performed by children
Analysis of nonsensical verbal forms in dreams particularly exhibits the dream-work's achievements in condensation
Essential dream-thoughts completely replace the dream and would be sufficient in themselves to replace it if there were no censorship
Dream-thoughts emerge as a complex structure with all the attributes of trains of thought familiar in waking life, often starting from more than one centre
Each train of dream-thought is almost invariably accompanied by its contradictory counterpart, linked by antithetical association
Dreams have no means at their disposal for representing logical relations like 'if', 'because', 'either-or' between dream-thoughts
Dreams disregard logical conjunctions and take over only the substantive content of dream-thoughts - restoration of connections is a task for interpretation
The incapacity of dreams to express logical relations lies in the nature of the psychical material out of which dreams are made, similar to plastic arts compared to poetry
Spoken sentences in dreams are unmodified or slightly modified reproductions of speeches found among recollections in dream-thoughts
Dreams reproduce logical connection by simultaneity in time, combining material into a single situation or event
When dreams show two elements close together, this guarantees some specially intimate connection between what corresponds to them among dream-thoughts
Causal relations are represented in dreams by temporal sequence - either as a sequence of introductory and main dream, or by direct transformation of one image into another
The alternative 'either-or' cannot be expressed in dreams - both alternatives are usually inserted as though they were equally valid
In the great majority of cases, the causal relation is not represented at all but is lost in the confusion of elements in the dreaming process
The most complicated achievements of thought are possible without the assistance of consciousness, as proven by psychoanalysis of hysteria and obsessions
Dream-thoughts may originate from the previous day, proceeding unobserved by consciousness and already completed at sleep onset
Becoming conscious is connected with the application of attention, a function only available in a specific quantity
Symbolism plays a part in dreams from the very first - dreamers have symbolism at their disposal from the earliest age
Temporal repetition of an act is regularly shown in dreams by numerical multiplication of an object
Psychoanalytic research finds no fundamental but only quantitative distinctions between normal and neurotic life
Analysis of dreams shows complete identity in mechanisms and symbolism between healthy and sick individuals - repressed complexes operate alike in both
Naive dreams of healthy people often contain simpler, more perspicuous and characteristic symbolism than those of neurotics
In neurotic dreams, symbolism may be obscure and hard to interpret due to more powerful workings of censorship and more far-reaching dream-distortion
Sexual flower symbolism occurs very commonly and symbolizes human sexual organs by blossoms, which are the sexual organs of plants
Gifts of flowers between lovers may have unconscious sexual meaning representing exchange of sexual gifts
Dreams can express thoughts of which the dreamer is scarcely aware in waking life, particularly thoughts concerned with sensual love and its organs
The meaning of symbols and significance of dreams can be arrived at with particular ease from dreams of people uninitiated into psychoanalysis
Dreams can represent serious thoughts far removed from anything sexual by means of infantile sexual material
In well-formed dreams there is nothing superfluous - every word is a symbol
The dream-work proper is not simply more careless or irrational than waking thought - it is completely different qualitatively and not immediately comparable with it
The dream-work does not think, calculate or judge at all - it restricts itself to giving things a new form
The dream has above all to evade censorship, and the dream-work uses displacement of psychical intensities to the point of a transvaluation of all psychical values
Thoughts must be reproduced exclusively or predominantly in visual and acoustic memory-traces, imposing considerations of representability on the dream-work
Extensive condensation serves to produce greater intensities than are available in dream-thoughts at night
Little attention is paid to logical relations between thoughts - those relations are given a disguised representation in certain formal characteristics of dreams
Affects attached to dream-thoughts undergo less modification than their ideational content - affects are suppressed or detached from proper ideas
Dreams are nothing other than a particular form of thinking made possible by conditions of the state of sleep - it is the dream-work which creates that form and is the essence of dreaming
Every dream contains the fulfillment of a wish - the dream was preferred to waking reflection because it could show the wished-for situation
positions.source: The Interpretation of Dreams (burning child dream)

positions.position: For the sake of wish fulfillment, sleep can be prolonged by one moment - the dream shows what is wished for as still present
Many analysts wrongly seek the essence of dreams in latent content, overlooking the distinction between latent dream-thoughts and dream-work
The content of dreams must have been overdetermined - words spoken in dreams are made up of words actually spoken in lifetime connected with important events
Memory of dreams is not only fragmentary but positively inaccurate and falsified - we may fill in what was never there with new material
Despite untrustworthiness of memory, it is just as important to interpret the smallest, least conspicuous and most uncertain constituents of dreams as the most clearly preserved
Precisely the most trivial elements of a dream are indispensable to its interpretation - work is held up if attention is not paid to them
We treat dream texts as Holy Writ what previous writers regarded as arbitrary improvisation hurriedly patched together
No conclusions upon construction and working methods of the mental instrument can be fully proved from investigation of dreams or any other mental function taken in isolation
Psychological hypotheses from dream analysis must remain in suspense until related to findings from other enquiries approaching the same problem from another angle
Dreams make use of the present tense in the same manner as day-dreams - the present tense is that in which wishes are represented as fulfilled
Not every dream exhibits transformation from idea into sensory image - there are dreams consisting only of thoughts which cannot be denied the essential nature of dreams
Transformation of ideas into sensory images also occurs in hallucinations and visions in health and as symptoms in psychoneuroses - this relation is not exclusive to dreams
The scene of action of dreams is different from that of waking ideational life - this makes the special peculiarities of dream-life intelligible
We picture the mental apparatus as a compound instrument of 'systems' arranged in temporal sequence through which excitation passes
All psychical activity starts from stimuli and ends in innervations - the apparatus has a sensory and motor end with a sense or direction
Reflex processes remain the model of every psychical function - the psychical apparatus must be constructed like a reflex apparatus
We must distribute perception and memory functions onto different systems - a system receives perceptions but retains no trace, while mnemic systems retain permanent modifications
Association consists in the fact that excitation is transmitted more readily from one mnemic element to another due to diminished resistances and facilitating paths
The perception system without capacity to retain modifications provides consciousness with sensory qualities, while memories even deeply stamped are themselves unconscious
What we describe as our character is based on memory-traces of impressions, especially those of earliest youth which scarcely ever become conscious
Memories can produce all their effects while in an unconscious condition - when they become conscious they exhibit no sensory quality or very slight quality
Formation of dreams required the hypothesis of two psychical agencies - one submitting the other's activity to criticism involving exclusion from consciousness
The critical agency stands closer to consciousness like a screen between the criticized agency and consciousness, and directs waking life and voluntary actions
The preconscious system allows excitatory processes to enter consciousness without impediment if certain conditions are fulfilled - it holds the key to voluntary movement
The unconscious system has no access to consciousness except via the preconscious, through which its excitatory process must submit to modifications
The motive force for producing dreams is supplied by the unconscious system - the dream-wish originates from the Ucs
